study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of various bronchoscopic lung volume reduction (BLVR) interventions, including their impact on 6-minute walking distance (6MWD), in COPD patients.
results_summary: The study found that endobronchial valve (EBV) treatment achieved clinically meaningful improvements in 6MWD and SGRQ scores at 6 months, while coils and bronchoscopic thermal vapor ablation (BTVA) showed benefits in SGRQ scores at longer follow-ups.
population_specificity: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients

study_goal: To assess the added value of caregiver-mediated exercises combined with telerehabilitation on self-reported mobility outcomes in subacute stroke patients compared to usual care alone.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in self-reported mobility outcomes between the intervention and control groups postintervention. Secondary outcomes, including functional outcomes and psychosocial wellbeing, were also explored, but the trial was underpowered to detect significant effects.
population_specificity: Forty-one patient-caregiver dyads within 3 months poststroke in the Netherlands.
effective_dosage: 2.5 hours per week of caregiver-mediated mobility exercises supported by telerehabilitation and four face-to-face sessions.

study_goal: To investigate the clinical effects and application value of self-made disseminating and descending breathing exercises on home rehabilitation of patients with stable COPD.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of the intervention.
population_specificity: 70 COPD patients admitted to the outpatient department from July 2019 to September 2021.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to conceptualize patient experience and disease activity in dermatomyositis (DM) to refine the development of the Dermatomyositis Disease Symptom Questionnaire (DM-DSQ), including symptoms like walking difficulties.
results_summary: The study identified walking as a functional impact of DM and found the DM-DSQ items relevant and comprehensive, except for "skin sensitivity in sunlight." The questionnaire showed preliminary content validity in the surveyed patient population.
population_specificity: 30 individuals with dermatomyositis (aged ≥ 18 years) in the US.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether home-based cardiac telerehabilitation, which includes walking, improves exercise endurance, disease burden status, cardiac function, and quality of life in patients after percutaneous coronary intervention.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in 6-minute walking test, anerobic threshold, V o2max, physical and mental component summary scores, and quality of life compared to the control group. These results suggest that home-based cardiac telerehabilitation, including walking, is effective in enhancing exercise endurance and reducing disease burden.
population_specificity: Patients after percutaneous coronary intervention (106 participants, 53 in each group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a walking aid training program, with or without telemonitoring, on fear of falling, mobility, quality of life, and fall risk in older adults treated in an emergency department.
results_summary: The study will assess the impact of walking aid training and telemonitoring on mobility, fear of falling, and fall risk at 3 and 6 months post-intervention, but results are not yet available as it is a planned randomized controlled trial.
population_specificity: Older adults cared for in a geriatric emergency department.
effective_dosage: Not specified (training and provision of walking aids, with telemonitoring every two weeks for the first three months in one group).
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 3 and 6 months post-discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supervised home-based tele-rehabilitation (SHTR) is non-inferior to center-based pulmonary rehabilitation for improving walking distance and other outcomes in COPD patients.
results_summary: The study focused on changes in the 6-minute walking distance as the primary outcome, along with secondary measures like sit-to-stand performance, respiratory muscle strength, and patient-reported scales. Results were not explicitly stated in the abstract, but the trial design suggests a rigorous comparison between home-based and center-based rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise training module details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neural basis of gait disorders in Dementia with Lewy Bodies (DLB) patients compared to Healthy Elderly Controls and Alzheimer's Disease patients.
results_summary: The study found correlations between walking speed and gray matter volume decreases in specific brain regions (e.g., caudate nuclei, cingulate cortex, hippocampi) in DLB patients, suggesting involvement of motivational, spatial, and motor components in gait disorders. No correlations were found for Timed Up and Go test or one-leg balance.
population_specificity: 84 DLB patients, 39 Alzheimer's Disease patients, and 22 Healthy Elderly Controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate and discuss the features of available outcome measures for assessing treatment efficacy in ambulant and non-ambulant Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) patients.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the challenges in correlating outcome scores with disease progression in DMD due to variability in patient characteristics and disease progression. It discusses the reliability and validity of existing outcome measures but notes their clinical significance is influenced by disease variability.
population_specificity: Ambulant and non-ambulant males with Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the safety and efficacy of the GEMS-H robotic hip exoskeleton in improving walking speed, endurance, and balance in poststroke individuals during outpatient rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in walking speed (0.13 m/s), endurance (47 m in 6-Minute Walk Test), balance (2.93 points on Berg Balance Scale), and daily step count (1,750 steps). Corticomotor excitability changes suggested potential correction of poststroke interhemispheric imbalance.
population_specificity: 41 participants with chronic stroke (average age 60, average stroke latency 6.5 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of different mask types on clinical parameters during moderate exercise (six-minute walk test) in healthy non-smokers, active smokers, and patients with interstitial lung disease (ILD).
results_summary: Participants with ILD showed significantly reduced walking distance, higher respiratory rate, and lower pO₂ when using FFP2 masks. The study compared outcomes across mask types but did not focus on walking itself as an intervention.
population_specificity: Healthy non-smokers (n=21), active smokers without known pulmonary disease (n=17), and patients with ILD (n=15).
study_duration: Single six-minute walk test per mask condition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Ba Duan Jin exercise on lung function and 6-minute walking distance in patients with stable COPD.
results_summary: The meta-analysis showed that Ba Duan Jin exercise significantly improved FEV1, FEV1/FVC, and 6-minute walking distance in stable COPD patients. The intervention's effectiveness was influenced by exercise duration, frequency, and adherence.
population_specificity: Patients with stable chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise frequency and duration varied by study).
study_duration: Varied by study (not explicitly stated in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers were investigating the safety and efficacy of mesenchymal stem/stromal cells (MSCs) derived from various tissues for treating ischemic cardiomyopathy and associated heart failure, not Walking.
results_summary: The study found that MSCs from bone marrow, umbilical cord, and adipose tissue were moderately well tolerated, with 67.3% of trials reporting death or serious adverse events. The mean increase in left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) was 5.75%, indicating a modest therapeutic effect.
population_specificity: Patients over 18 years of age with ischemic cardiomyopathy and associated heart failure.

study_goal: To determine the effects of a Partial Body Weight Support harness system in a play-enriched environment on gross motor development and mastery motivation in infants with Down Syndrome.
results_summary: The study found statistically and clinically significant improvements in gross motor function but no significant changes in mastery motivation. The direct impact of the harness alone remains unclear.
population_specificity: Pre-walking infants with Down Syndrome (n=17).
effective_dosage: 3 times per week for 3 weeks (with a 1-week washout).
study_duration: 3 weeks per condition (total 7 weeks including washout).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early motor skill delays, including walking, could serve as markers for neurodevelopmental conditions.
results_summary: The study found significant delays in walking (g= 0.71) among infants who later developed neurodevelopmental conditions, particularly autism and DCD, compared to controls. These findings suggest walking delays may be an early indicator of such conditions.
population_specificity: Infants who later received clinical diagnoses of autism, ADHD, schizophrenia, language conditions, tic disorders, or DCD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of eHealth technologies on physical functioning and health-related quality of life (HRQoL) in people with lung cancer, focusing on interventions like walking.
results_summary: The review found that eHealth technologies, including web-based applications and mobile apps, improved walking distance, muscle strength, balance, dyspnea symptoms, fatigue, and HRQoL in lung cancer patients. However, long-term impacts and clinical implementation were not well-documented.
population_specificity: People with lung cancer aged >18 years.
study_duration: Studies conducted between 2010-2018, but exact intervention durations not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to document a rare case of pyogenic spondylodiscitis and empyema caused by Staphylococcus aureus, highlighting its impact on walking ability and functional recovery.
results_summary: The patient initially experienced severe motor dysfunction (paraplegia) but gradually regained walking ability with a grasping gait after intensive rehabilitation. The infection was successfully managed, but functional recovery was partial.
population_specificity: A 79-year-old Japanese man with type 2 diabetes mellitus and polymyalgia rheumatica.
study_duration: Rehabilitation continued until at least 45 postoperative days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the acute effects of aquatic walking/running versus dry-land walking/running on blood glucose and plasma renin activity (PRA) in individuals with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in PRA (-69%) only after the aquatic session, but no comparable effect was observed for dry-land walking/running. Blood glucose changes were not explicitly detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Individuals with type 2 diabetes (mean age 53.2 ± 8.9 years, diagnosed for 6.3 ± 6.34 years).
effective_dosage: Seven blocks of 3 min at 85-90% of the heart rate deflection point (HRDP), interspersed with 2 min at <85% HRDP, totaling 35 min per session.
study_duration: Two sessions with a 48 h interval.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mandatory use of a step tracker app in PE classes could create a lasting walking habit in adolescents and improve physical activity levels, body composition, and fitness.
results_summary: Mandatory use of step tracker apps temporarily improved physical activity, body composition, and fitness, but these benefits disappeared once the intervention ended, with only 8.3% of adolescents continuing the practice. No lasting changes were observed in body composition or fitness after the non-mandatory period.
population_specificity: 357 adolescents in compulsory secondary education (mean age 13.92 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (step tracker app use after school hours).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of chiropractic rehabilitation therapy versus traditional rehabilitation therapy in improving walking gait and other functional outcomes in Crowe IV DDH patients after total hip arthroplasty.
results_summary: The study found that chiropractic rehabilitation therapy significantly improved walking gait, reduced limp, shortened affected limb length, decreased pain (VAS score), improved hip function (Harris Hip Score), and reduced pelvic tilt compared to traditional rehabilitation therapy, though muscle strength improvement was not statistically significant between groups.
population_specificity: 72 patients with Crowe IV developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) post-total hip arthroplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of botulinum neurotoxin A (BoNT-A) injections on walking energy cost, capacity, physical activity, mobility, and pain in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in energy cost of walking between BoNT-A and placebo groups at any time point, but there was some evidence of reduced pain intensity in the BoNT-A group.
population_specificity: Children (4-16 years) with spastic cerebral palsy classified in GMFCS levels I and II.
effective_dosage: Single injections of BoNT-A or 0.9% saline into calf muscles (specific dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 4, 12, and 24 weeks post-injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of botulinum toxin A (BoNT-A) combined with rehabilitation for improving lower-limb spasticity and walking function in patients with upper motor neuron syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that BoNT-A therapy, when combined with rehabilitation, improved spasticity, ankle joint range of motion, and gait patterns. Key strategies included proper muscle identification, rehabilitation integration, and frequent BoNT-A administration to maintain effects.
population_specificity: Patients with upper motor neuron syndrome and lower-limb spasticity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare outcomes of early versus late initiation of IVIG treatment in patients with anti-HMGCR immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy (IMNM), focusing on muscle weakness and disability.
results_summary: Early IVIG treatment significantly improved muscle strength and reduced permanent disability compared to delayed treatment, with better outcomes in manual muscle testing and total improvement scores at 3, 6, and 12 months. Delayed treatment was associated with higher rates of permanent residual weakness requiring walking aids.
population_specificity: 31 adult patients with anti-HMGCR IMNM from the Oregon Health and Science University Myositis Center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early enforced mobilization (walking) could reduce postoperative complications and enhance recovery in patients undergoing pancreatic surgery.
results_summary: Early enforced mobilization did not reduce postoperative complications but improved postoperative mobilization, gastrointestinal function recovery, and patient-perceived quality of recovery. No significant differences were found in other secondary outcomes like pulmonary complications or mortality.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing pancreatic surgery at a tertiary hospital in China.
effective_dosage: Professional assistance with first ambulation on postoperative day 1 and family-involved supervision to achieve daily walking goals.
study_duration: Intervention administered from postoperative day 1 to day 7.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of different forms of walking in reducing symptoms of depression and anxiety.
results_summary: Walking significantly reduced depressive and anxiety symptoms compared to inactive controls, with comparable effects to active controls. The benefits were consistent across various walking formats, frequencies, and durations, with greater effects observed in depressed participants.
population_specificity: Adults, including both depressed and non-depressed individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical and radiological outcomes of single-position OLIF with navigation (S-OLIF) versus dual-position OLIF (D-OLIF) in patients undergoing single-level OLIF.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in back and leg pain, Oswestry disability index, or walking distance improvements between S-OLIF and D-OLIF. However, S-OLIF showed higher improvement in quality of life (EuroQol 5-dimension 5-level index), fewer cases of pedicle screw malposition, and shorter surgery time.
population_specificity: 102 patients who underwent single-level OLIF at a single institution (55 in S-OLIF group, 47 in D-OLIF group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the tolerability, side effects, and subjective treatment outcomes of ofatumumab in patients with multiple sclerosis, including its impact on quality of life and walking distance.
results_summary: Patients reported increased headaches and limb pain as persistent side effects but noted a very positive effect on quality of life. No EDSS worsening or treatment discontinuations occurred during the observation period.
population_specificity: 81 patients with multiple sclerosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the decline in motor function and gait in adults with cerebral palsy (CP) as they age and propose mechanistic explanations for these changes.
results_summary: The study found that adults with CP experience increasing walking difficulties and dependency on assistive devices as they age, particularly around 30-40 years, with neuromuscular and cardiovascular alterations occurring earlier than in typically developing peers. Comorbid diagnoses and ageing contribute to these declines.
population_specificity: Adults with cerebral palsy (CP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate a novel two-level machine learning model's ability to assess arm movement abnormality during walking in people with acquired brain injury (ABI).
results_summary: The machine learning predictions showed similar agreement to experienced human assessors, with no statistically significant differences, though the networks slightly under-predicted scores with small effect sizes. The study suggests machine learning can perform comparably to clinicians in assessing arm movement abnormality in ABI patients.
population_specificity: People with acquired brain injury (ABI) (n=42) and healthy controls (n=34).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of institution-based versus self-managed walking programmes in increasing daily physical activity levels among chronic stroke survivors with spastic hemiparesis.
results_summary: The study expects institution-based walking programmes to be more effective than self-managed programmes in increasing physical activity, measured by daily step counts, with secondary outcomes including improvements in walking ability, endurance, balance, quality of life, and exercise motivation.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic stroke spastic hemiparesis who can walk for 6 minutes.

study_goal: To compare the effect of different types of telehealth interventions on the efficacy and adherence of patients with cardiovascular disease in cardiac rehabilitation.
results_summary: Telehealth cardiac rehabilitation improved peak oxygen uptake (VO2) and adherence, with combinations of two or more telehealth interventions being particularly effective.
population_specificity: Patients with cardiovascular disease participating in cardiac rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility and efficacy of a remotely-delivered, 16-week exercise training program (including walking) for improving cognitive and physical functions in older adults with multiple sclerosis (MS) and moderate mobility disability.
results_summary: The study proposed a randomized controlled trial to evaluate the effects of combined aerobic and resistance exercise (including walking) on physical activity, cognitive function, mobility, and quality of life in older adults with MS, with outcomes measured at baseline, post-intervention (16 weeks), and follow-up (32 weeks).
population_specificity: Older adults (age ≥ 50 years) with multiple sclerosis and moderate mobility disability but without severe cognitive impairment.

study_goal: To determine the relationship between postoperative physiotherapy activities (including walking) and outcomes like hospital length of stay and discharge destination after hip fracture surgery.
results_summary: Earlier walking, higher activity on postoperative day 1, and more frequent physiotherapy sessions were associated with shorter hospital stays and higher likelihood of returning home. Delayed walking or reduced activity correlated with longer stays and lower odds of returning to private residence.
population_specificity: Hip fracture surgery patients aged ≥50 years (56% aged ≥85, 62% female, 38% cognitively impaired pre-injury).
effective_dosage: Not specified (frequency of physiotherapy sessions varied).
study_duration: Variable (acute LOS median: 8 days; total LOS median: 20 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess bone consolidation rates under septic conditions in patients treated for bone and joint infection with hardware retention, and to evaluate functional outcomes including walking.
results_summary: The study found a bone healing rate of 73.5% at a mean of 24 weeks, with no significant impact of time to revision on consolidation. Functional results, including walking, were assessed but specific outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients aged over 15 years with infection after internal fixation or fusion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss the ethical and practical implications of exoskeleton technologies, including their potential to restore or enhance walking capacity.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the potential of exoskeletons to improve mobility and strength but raises ethical concerns regarding data privacy, accessibility, and user autonomy, particularly in medical, industrial, and military contexts.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of exoskeleton applications)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding inspiratory muscle training (IMT) to standard pulmonary rehabilitation (PR), which included walking, improved exercise capacity, dyspnea, fatigue, and quality of life in BLVR-eligible patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in exercise capacity improvement between the group receiving standard PR (including walking) and the group receiving PR plus IMT. However, both groups showed improvements in dyspnea, fatigue, depression scores, 6MWD, MEP, peripheral muscle strength, IPAQ-SF, and SGRQ scores.
population_specificity: Sixty-four patients eligible for bronchoscopic lung volume reduction (BLVR).
effective_dosage: Not specified for walking (part of standard PR program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the safety, feasibility, and efficacy of a home-based resistance training program delivered via an innovative technological solution in healthy older adults.
results_summary: The intervention was safe and feasible, with no adverse events reported. It positively affected walking parameters and lower limbs' maximal force but showed no effect on body composition, balance, or muscle power.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults (73 participants, 36 females).
effective_dosage: 3 sessions per week (target adherence was 61% in the first trimester).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility, safety, and tumor biological activity of exercise therapy (moderate-intensity treadmill walking) in inactive men with localized prostate cancer, identifying a recommended phase 2 dose.
results_summary: The study found that all tested exercise doses (90–450 minutes/week) were feasible and safe, with no serious adverse events. The most promising activity was observed at 225 minutes/week, showing reductions in tumor cell proliferation (Ki67) and prostate-specific antigen levels.
population_specificity: 53 inactive men with treatment-naive localized prostate cancer scheduled for surgical resection (median age 61 years).
effective_dosage: Escalated doses of 90, 150, 225, 300, 375, and 450 minutes per week of moderate-intensity treadmill walking.
study_duration: Intervention duration varied by dose level, administered until surgical resection (specific timeframe not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the rising incidence of scurvy, particularly its orthopaedic manifestations, including difficulty walking, in pediatric patients.
results_summary: The study found an increasing incidence of scurvy in pediatric inpatients, with common musculoskeletal reports including difficulty walking, knee pain, and lower limb deformity. Patients with scurvy had greater disease burden, including longer hospital stays and higher charges.
population_specificity: Pediatric inpatients (2016-2020, n=19,413,465) with scurvy, predominantly younger, male, low-income, and obese, often with autism spectrum disorder.

study_goal: To examine the impact of trimetazidine on skeletal muscle function, particularly walking performance, in patients with peripheral artery disease.
results_summary: Trimetazidine significantly improved Maximum Walking Distance and Time, as well as Pain Onset Time, but had no significant effect on Ankle-Brachial Index. The study concluded that trimetazidine has anti-ischaemic benefits for walking performance in these patients.
population_specificity: 172 patients with intermittent claudication due to peripheral artery disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to expand clinical and genetic information about LGMD2G/R7, including its worldwide distribution and disease progression, particularly regarding the need for walking aids.
results_summary: The study found that individuals with LGMD2G/R7 required walking aids after a median of 21 years, with women progressing 13 years slower than men. LGMD2G/R7 was identified in Brazil, China, and Bulgaria, with 119 cases globally, suggesting possible founder effects in these populations.
population_specificity: Individuals with limb-girdle muscular dystrophy type 2G/R7 (LGMD2G/R7), primarily from Brazil, China, and Bulgaria.
study_duration: Data reviewed from July 2017 to August 2023 (6 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of knee flexion position and sex on femoral cartilage outcomes and the association between gait biomechanics and cartilage features.
results_summary: The study found that cartilage thickness varied by knee flexion angle and sex, with males showing thicker cartilage than females. No association was detected between gait biomechanics and cartilage outcomes.
population_specificity: 50 individuals (25 males and 25 females; average age 20.62 years).

study_goal: To investigate the effects of combining rTMS and ARGAT on motor function in survivors of stroke.
results_summary: Both groups showed significant improvements in walking speed, symmetry index, affected step length, affected stride length, FMA-LE, and BBS scores, with the combination of rTMS and ARGAT demonstrating superior effects compared to ARGAT alone.
population_specificity: Survivors of stroke
effective_dosage: 20 sessions over four weeks (five consecutive daily sessions)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of robotic-assisted gait training (Walkbot) combined with physiotherapy compared to physiotherapy alone in improving walking ability in children and adolescents with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found that the Walkbot-assisted treatment significantly improved standing, muscle strength, and knee range of motion compared to physiotherapy alone, with notable differences in the Gross Motor Function Measure-88 dimensions.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with cerebral palsy.
effective_dosage: 4 sessions per week of 40 minutes each with the Walkbot.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if education through home visits, mobile app use (Google Fit), group walking, and phone reminders improved health promotion and physical activity in elderly individuals.
results_summary: The intervention group showed higher healthy lifestyle habits scores compared to the control group, with a high effect size (0.577) and statistically significant results (p < 0.05). The study suggests that repeated reminders and interventions can promote healthy behaviors in the elderly.
population_specificity: 66 elderly individuals (33 intervention, 33 control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of overground robot-assisted gait training (RAGT) using a wearable exoskeletal robot in improving motor function and gait in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found that RAGT significantly improved gross motor function (GMFM-88, GMFM-66), balance control, and gait patterns compared to standard physical therapy, with sustained benefits observed at a 4-week follow-up.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy (Gross Motor Function Classification System levels II to IV), mean age 9.51 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify pre- and perioperative predictors of pain during walking in the subacute postoperative period (Days 2-7) following total knee arthroplasty.
results_summary: The study found that postoperative pain during walking at 24 hours was a strong predictor of subacute pain (Days 2-7), while preoperative pain was only weakly predictive. The best predictive accuracy for high-subacute pain was achieved with a VAS cut-off of 45.5 at 24 hours postoperatively.
population_specificity: 227 patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty, participating in two randomized trials.
study_duration: Pain was assessed on Days 2, 4, and 7 postoperatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of ankle foot orthoses (AFOs) on electromyography (EMG) activity during walking in individuals with neuromuscular impairment.
results_summary: The review found that AFO interventions had diverse effects on EMG activity, with variability in direction and interpretation across studies. Longitudinal studies refuted concerns about adverse effects on EMG activity, supporting the safety of prolonged AFO use.
population_specificity: Individuals with neuromuscular impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze baseline characteristics and app usage frequencies to identify factors contributing to successful weight loss through dietary and physical activity interventions via smartphone apps.
results_summary: The study found a negative association between certain baseline characteristics or app usage frequencies and weight loss success, as indicated by logistic regression analysis (OR: 0.248). Specific factors contributing to successful weight loss remained uncertain.
population_specificity: 68 Japanese adults with overweight and obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if personalized prescription of pacing (PPoP) could reduce left ventricular mid-cavity obstructive gradients and improve symptoms in patients with refractory hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
results_summary: PPoP significantly reduced obstruction gradients (60% reduction) and improved exercise performance in severely symptomatic patients, with LV pacing achieving maximum gradient reduction in 88% of patients.
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic, drug-refractory left ventricular mid-cavity obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the experiences and acceptability of music-cued motor imagery (MCMI), music-cued gait training (MCGT), and combined MCMI-MCGT in people with multiple sclerosis (pwMS), as well as assess self-rated health status postintervention.
results_summary: Participants reported positive changes in walking, fatigue, and overall health postintervention, with themes including empowerment, synchronization, and real-world transfer. However, challenges like concentration issues and difficulty synchronizing with music cues were noted.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (pwMS) with mild to moderate disability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of arm-ergometry and treadmill exercise training on cardiorespiratory fitness and walking distances in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: Arm-ergometry was noninferior to treadmill training for improving peak oxygen uptake (VO2peak), but treadmill training led to greater improvements in walking distance and self-perceived walking ability. Both interventions improved VO2 at the first ventilatory threshold, with arm-ergometry showing better ventilatory efficiency.
population_specificity: Symptomatic patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD), predominantly male (88%), average age 66 ± 8 years.
effective_dosage: 12-week supervised exercise training protocol (arm-ergometry or treadmill).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of multiperiscopic peripheral prisms versus Fresnel peripheral prisms in improving blind-side collision detection for individuals with homonymous hemianopia while walking.
results_summary: Blind-side collision detection improved from 23% without prisms to 73% with prisms. Multiperiscopic prisms significantly outperformed Fresnel prisms at a 40° bearing angle (88% vs. 38% detection).
population_specificity: Six participants with homonymous hemianopia.
study_duration: Minimum of 4 weeks of daily prism use before testing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of iron deficiency on fatigue, quality of life, cognition, and physical ability in patients undergoing evaluation for colorectal cancer.
results_summary: Iron deficiency was not associated with fatigue, quality of life, or cognition but might affect aerobic endurance and peripheral muscle strength to a clinically relevant degree.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing evaluation for colorectal cancer (201 participants, 57% iron deficient).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily step goals and feedback through a fitness tracker could reduce postoperative complications after major abdominal surgery.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in postoperative morbidity between the experimental group (receiving step goals and feedback) and the control group. Secondary outcomes, including quality of recovery and step count, were also comparable between groups.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing major abdominal surgery, with a mean age of 58 years, 71% of whom had malignant disease (pancreatic, colorectal, or hepatobiliary malignancies).
effective_dosage: Not specified (daily step goals were provided, but exact step counts are not detailed).
study_duration: Intervention lasted until postoperative day 7, with follow-up at 30 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if the Interactive Walkway (IWW) could sensitively and specifically measure drug-induced effects on walking adaptability and fall risk in elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found that zolpidem impaired walking adaptability, TUG performance, adaptive tracking, and body sway for 3 hours post-dose, while suvorexant only increased body sway. The IWW successfully distinguished between the effects of the two drugs.
population_specificity: Healthy elderly individuals aged 65-80 years.
effective_dosage: 5 mg zolpidem, 10 mg suvorexant, or placebo administered once in the morning.
study_duration: Assessments were performed pre-dose and hourly until 9 hours post-dose.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 12 weeks of overground gait training with a robotic exoskeleton outside the clinical setting improves walking ability, muscle activity, and overall motor function in individuals with neuromuscular disorders.
results_summary: The study found that a wearable robotic exoskeleton with precisely timed assistive torque improved knee extension during walking, with continued improvement over an acute practice period. Interleaved assistance and resistance also enhanced knee extension and muscle activation, suggesting potential for long-term muscle strengthening.
population_specificity: Individuals with neuromuscular disorders, specifically children with cerebral palsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate changes in postoperative mobility status in patients with adult spinal deformity (ASD) and identify factors influencing these changes and their impact on clinical outcomes.
results_summary: Two years postoperatively, 87% of patients maintained or improved mobility, but 27% showed decreased mobility at discharge, linked to lower home discharge rates and limited long-term improvement. Overcorrection in sagittal alignment (increased thoracic kyphosis and lower lumbar lordosis) was associated with mobility decline.
population_specificity: 299 patients with ASD who underwent multi-segment posterior spinal fusion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate changes in whole-brain networks after stroke and the therapeutic mechanisms of robot-assisted gait training (RAGT) on walking function.
results_summary: Stroke patients showed reduced small-worldness and network efficiency compared to healthy subjects. RAGT improved lower limb motor function, balance, and walking function, with these improvements correlated with normalization of brain network metrics.
population_specificity: 21 stroke patients and 20 healthy subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the biomechanical responses of shallow water walking between older adults with Parkinson's disease and age-matched healthy individuals.
results_summary: Both groups reduced walking speed similarly with increased immersion depth, but Parkinson's patients achieved this by decreasing stride frequency and length. The Parkinson's group had a shorter contact phase at waist depth, likely due to reduced fall risk and drag force effects, while joint motion range was similar between groups.
population_specificity: Older adults with Parkinson's disease (10 participants) and age-matched healthy individuals (10 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the impact of ankle fusion (AF) and total ankle arthroplasty (TAA) on postoperative gait parameters in patients with end-stage ankle disease.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in most spatiotemporal gait parameters (e.g., walking speed, cadence) between AF and TAA patients, but TAA patients showed significantly higher sagittal ankle range of motion (ROM), particularly in dorsiflexion. Results for hip and knee ROM were inconsistent.
population_specificity: Patients with end-stage ankle disease (e.g., severe arthritis) who underwent either ankle fusion or total ankle arthroplasty.

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of balance training using touch controller-based fully immersive virtual reality (FIVR) devices on balance and walking abilities in patients with stroke.
results_summary: Touch controller-based FIVR balance training significantly improved balance (Berg Balance Scale and timed up-and-go test) and gait abilities (velocity, step length, stride length, and single limb support) in stroke patients. The improvements were statistically significant (P < .01).
population_specificity: Patients with stroke (n = 36, split into FIVR and control groups).
effective_dosage: 3 sessions of 30 minutes per week for 5 weeks (FIVR group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current evidence for treatment strategies for pectus defects, including supportive care and surgical interventions, but did not specifically study Walking.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about Walking's effects, only noting that severe pectus defects can limit moderate activity such as walking in some patients.
population_specificity: Patients with pectus defects (excavatum, carinatum, arcuatum, or mixed defects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of telerehabilitation, including walking, on clinical symptoms, physical function, psychological function, and quality of life in post-COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: Telerehabilitation, including walking, significantly improved physical function (e.g., 30-second sit-to-stand test, 6-minute walking distance) but did not show significant improvements in clinical symptoms, pulmonary function, psychological function, or quality of life. The treatment was safe with no severe adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Patients with post-COVID-19 (n=1129 across 16 RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a gamified intervention with a support partner could effectively increase walking and physical activity in older adults at genetic risk for Alzheimer's disease and related dementias.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a significantly greater increase in mean daily step count (1699 steps/day) compared to the control group, which was sustained during follow-up (1219 steps/day). Higher self-reported risk perception was associated with increased activity, but genetic risk status did not influence outcomes.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 70, 78% female) at genetic risk for Alzheimer's disease and related dementias, enrolled in a national AD prevention registry (GeneMatch).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 12-week walking intervention combined with a hypocaloric diet improves body composition and functional capacity in overweight men compared to other exercise types or no exercise.
results_summary: The walking group showed improvements in cardiorespiratory fitness, maintained leg muscle force, but experienced a decline in skeletal muscle mass. The greatest overall improvements were seen in the combined exercise group.
population_specificity: 60 healthy adult men who are overweight
effective_dosage: 60 minutes per session, 3 days a week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the impact of increased weight on chronic oedema/lymphoedema of the leg and related factors, including mobility (walking with aid or being chair-bound).
results_summary: Increased weight was associated with decreased mobility (walking with aid OR 1.9, being chair bound OR 1.2) and more advanced stages of chronic oedema. Obesity negatively impacted chronic oedema control, function, appearance, symptoms, and quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients with clinically confirmed chronic oedema/lymphoedema of the leg (n=7397) from 38 centers across nine countries, categorized by BMI (normal weight, class I-II obesity, class III obesity).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the effectiveness of a personalized, case formulation approach to treating PTSD, not Walking.
results_summary: The abstract does not mention Walking or its effects; it focuses on PTSD treatment approaches.
population_specificity: Patients with posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare medical complications, in-hospital mortality, and postoperative recovery between patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty (THA) for femoral neck fractures versus elective patients with coxarthrosis.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in preoperative comorbidities or short-term complications between the two groups. Patients with femoral neck fractures had slightly faster mobilization by active walking (2.77 vs. 3.1 days) but longer hospital stays (13.41 vs. 11.07 days) compared to elective OA patients.
population_specificity: Patients older than 45 years undergoing THA for primary/secondary hip arthritis or displaced femoral neck fractures (Garden III and IV).
study_duration: Follow-up at 3 days, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year postoperatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and effectiveness of the MI-Walk intervention, combining motivational enhancement therapy and home-based brisk walking, for gastrointestinal cancer survivors undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: The MI-Walk intervention showed adequate enrollment and retention, with Fitbit and counseling rated as most helpful. Acceptability and adherence varied based on participant characteristics, suggesting the need for tailored interventions.
population_specificity: Stage II-IV gastrointestinal cancer survivors receiving chemotherapy (mean age 56.79, 97% white, 79% male).
effective_dosage: 8-week intervention with motivational interviewing sessions, Fitbit use, exercise diaries, and optional weekly walking groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the symptomatology, risk factors, and cultural challenges associated with functional neurological disorder, including difficulty walking as one of its manifestations.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that functional neurological disorder can manifest as difficulty walking, among other symptoms, and emphasizes the need for timely diagnosis and intervention considering psychosocial and cultural factors.
population_specificity: Patients with functional neurological disorder, particularly in Asian countries like Pakistan, with a focus on those experiencing abuse or trauma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of home-based neurostimulation on upper and lower limb function in stroke patients.
results_summary: Home-based neurostimulation improved upper limb muscle strength, functional mobility, and walking endurance post-intervention and at follow-up, with statistically significant results.
population_specificity: Stroke patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the feasibility of a cable-driven robotic hippotherapy system for improving trunk posture control and walking function in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The robotic hippotherapy group showed significant improvement in trunk control compared to the conventional group, but no significant improvements were observed in gross motor function, walking speed, or walking distance.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy (average age 6.4 ± 3.0 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the five-year outcomes of decompression alone versus decompression with fusion surgery for lumbar spinal stenosis, with or without degenerative spondylolisthesis, focusing on walking-related outcomes.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in five-year Oswestry Disability Index (ODI) between decompression alone and decompression with fusion. However, decompression alone showed better results in EQ-5D and patient-reported leg pain reduction, particularly in patients without degenerative spondylolisthesis. Reoperation rates were similar between groups.
population_specificity: 247 patients with one- or two-level central lumbar spinal stenosis, with or without degenerative spondylolisthesis (mean age 67 years; 67% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of noninvasive cerebellar stimulation (NiCBS) on motor recovery, including walking, in stroke patients and propose a framework for its use.
results_summary: NiCBS showed moderate to high effect sizes in improving walking outcomes after stroke, suggesting its potential to enhance movement recovery. The study also proposed a conceptual framework to optimize NiCBS and behavioral interventions for specific deficits.
population_specificity: Individuals with supratentorial stroke

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether thiamine supplementation provides therapeutic benefits for patients with chronic heart failure (CHF).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant effect of thiamine treatment on left ventricular ejection fraction in CHF patients compared to placebo, concluding that thiamine supplementation does not have a direct therapeutic effect on CHF.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic heart failure (CHF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the feasibility of a school-based walking intervention for children with intellectual disability.
results_summary: The intervention was acceptable to staff and pupils, with an 84% uptake rate of walking sessions. Challenges included COVID-19 disruptions and accelerometer data collection difficulties.
population_specificity: Children with intellectual disability aged 9-13 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of tadalafil in patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction and combined postcapillary and precapillary pulmonary hypertension, including its impact on 6-minute walking distance.
results_summary: The study found no significant benefit of tadalafil over placebo in reducing heart failure hospitalization or all-cause death, nor in improving 6-minute walking distance. The trial was terminated early due to medication supply issues, limiting conclusive findings.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction and combined postcapillary and precapillary pulmonary hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how replacing or interrupting prolonged sitting with light-intensity walking affects glucose metabolism and heart rate variability in young adults with overweight and obesity.
results_summary: Light-intensity walking significantly lowered blood glucose levels and improved heart rate variability compared to uninterrupted sitting during an 8-hour workday simulation.
population_specificity: Young adults (mean age 23.4 years) with overweight and obesity (BMI 29.7 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: Continuous walking at 1.0 mph during an 8-hour simulated workday.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the health benefits of walking as a form of physical activity, particularly its role in reducing morbidity and mortality, improving quality of life, and its emerging significance in cancer prevention and management.
results_summary: Walking is associated with reduced all-cause and cardiovascular disease mortality, potential cancer prevention, improved quality of life in cancer patients, and psychological benefits. It also helps mitigate chemotherapy side effects and reduces sarcopenia.
population_specificity: General population, elderly subjects, and cancer patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of combined botulinum toxin type A and focal extracorporeal shock wave therapy versus botulinum toxin alone on spasticity reduction in brain injury patients, particularly focusing on walking improvements.
results_summary: Combined therapy reduced spasticity more effectively (2-point reduction on the Ashworth Scale) and for a longer duration (up to week 25) compared to botulinum toxin alone (1-point reduction, lasting until week 17). The 10-meter walk test also showed faster improvements with combined therapy.
population_specificity: Brain injury patients with spasticity and lower limb involvement affecting walking.
effective_dosage: Botulinum toxin type A (dosage not specified) + 1 session/week of focal extracorporeal shock wave therapy for 3 weeks.
study_duration: 3 weeks (shock wave therapy), with follow-up at 1, 4, and 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a medial off-loader brace with sensor monitoring and a phone app improves outcomes for individuals with knee osteoarthritis compared to a brace-only intervention.
results_summary: The brace+sensor group showed higher retention, significant improvements in pain and activities of daily living beyond clinically important differences, and better functional outcomes (e.g., 6-min walk test) compared to the brace-only group. Both groups improved in some functional measures, but the sensor group had additional benefits like weight reduction.
population_specificity: Individuals aged 40-75 with knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (brace use and 12-week self-guided exercise program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of conservative treatments, such as proper footwear and foot orthoses, in managing hallux valgus (HV) and its impact on walking.
results_summary: The study found that proper footwear with specific features (wide toe box, cushioned sole, lowered heel) and personalized 3D printed toe spreaders improved symptoms and provided pain relief in HV patients. Foot orthoses, particularly dynamic biomechanical types, showed variable results in correcting HV or slowing its progression, with some studies noting symptom improvement.
population_specificity: Adults, particularly those over 65, with hallux valgus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and risks of testosterone therapy for middle-aged and older men with symptoms of hypogonadism but no identifiable hypothalamic-pituitary-testicular pathology.
results_summary: Testosterone therapy modestly improved energy, mood, sexual function, muscle strength, timed walking distance, and bone density, but increased the risk of trauma-related fractures without significantly raising risks of myocardial infarction, stroke, or prostate cancer.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and older men with symptoms and possible signs of hypogonadism, low or low-normal serum testosterone, and no HPT pathology.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of physical rehabilitation, including walking, compared to non-rehabilitation interventions for improving physical functioning and quality of life in long-term care residents with dementia.
results_summary: The review found low-certainty evidence that physical rehabilitation, including walking, improved activities of daily living and lower extremity function, but effects on specific functional tasks (e.g., gait speed) and quality of life were unclear or showed no significant change.
population_specificity: Long-term care residents with dementia of any severity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a seismograph-based algorithm for quantifying human gait, comparing its accuracy to clinical reference systems.
results_summary: The study found strong positive correlations between gait parameters measured by seismographs and those from reference systems (pressure-sensitive walkway and camera system), indicating the algorithm's effectiveness in assessing walking patterns.
population_specificity: 50 healthy participants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of optimized rate-adaptive pacing using the minute ventilation (MV) sensor on exercise tolerance, specifically walking distance, in elderly cardiac resynchronization therapy pacemaker (CRT-P) patients with chronotropic incompetence (CI).
results_summary: The study found that MV sensor-based DDDR mode increased heart rate in CI patients similarly to non-CI patients, leading to a significant improvement in walking distance (349 ± 132 m vs. 376 ± 128 m at 1 and 3 months, respectively, p < 0.05). Additionally, DDDR reduced heart rate score (HRSc) by 14% in those with severe CI (HRSc ≥ 70%, p < 0.001).
population_specificity: Older patients (median age 76 years) with a guideline-based indication for CRT and chronotropic incompetence.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of excessive reactive oxygen species (ROS) in the pathophysiology of peripheral artery disease (PAD) and explore potential antioxidant therapies, including the Keap1-Nrf2 pathway, to improve vascular function, skeletal muscle function, walking capacity, and quality of life in PAD patients.
results_summary: The study highlights that excessive ROS production in PAD impairs vascular and skeletal muscle function, contributing to reduced physical capabilities. It suggests antioxidant therapies, particularly targeting the Keap1-Nrf2 pathway, may help combat ROS accumulation and improve vascular function and physical performance in PAD patients.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the physiological and clinical effects of functional electrical stimulation cycling (FES-cycling) compared to other therapeutic modalities.
results_summary: FES-cycling showed statistically and clinically significant improvements in metabolic, cardiocirculatory, ventilatory, and muscle oxygen extraction variables, as well as cardiorespiratory fitness, lean mass, and physical fitness, with moderate-to-high certainty of evidence. No significant differences were found in 6-minute walking distance, muscle cross-sectional area, bone density, or ICU stay length.
population_specificity: Not specified (studies involving randomized controlled trials with FES-cycling interventions were included).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether semaglutide improved functional status (NYHA class) and other outcomes in patients with obesity-related heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF).
results_summary: Semaglutide improved NYHA functional class, HF-related symptoms, physical limitations, exercise function (6MWD), and reduced bodyweight and biomarkers of inflammation/congestion, with pronounced benefits in NYHA classes III/IV. Fewer patients on semaglutide experienced deterioration in functional class compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity-related HFpEF (1,145 participants across two trials).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to assess the baseline characteristics and treatment effect of semaglutide by sex in patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) and obesity.
results_summary: The study found that semaglutide improved heart failure-related symptoms, physical limitations, and exercise function similarly in both sexes, but reduced body weight more in women. Fewer serious adverse events were reported with semaglutide compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure (HF), left ventricular ejection fraction ≥45%, and body mass index ≥30 kg/m², including those with type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize cutoff values of motor and cognitive function for predicting or discriminating levels of activities of daily living (ADLs) after stroke, particularly focusing on walking independence.
results_summary: The study found that NIHSS score ≤8 and mRMI score ≥19 at acute hospitalization predict good functional and walking independence, respectively. Additionally, 288-367.5 m on the 6-min walk test and 25.5-27.6 points on the FMA-LL can discriminate community and noncommunity walkers.
population_specificity: Stroke patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the biomechanical stability of two proximal screw placement techniques (three-point fixation vs. intramedullary) in minimally invasive chevron and akin (MICA) procedures for hallux valgus correction.
results_summary: Three-point fixation demonstrated significantly higher bending stiffness (84% greater), lower dorsal angulation (one-third that of intramedullary), and higher load to failure (30% greater) compared to intramedullary constructs, indicating superior biomechanical stability. Both techniques tolerated the walking fatigue test without failure.
population_specificity: Six matched pairs of human fresh frozen cadaveric feet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of an individualized, progressive walking and education intervention to prevent the recurrence of low back pain.
results_summary: The walking intervention significantly reduced low back pain recurrence, with a median time to recurrence of 208 days in the intervention group compared to 112 days in the control group. The intervention was also cost-effective, with a 94% probability of being cost-effective at a willingness-to-pay threshold of AU$28,000.
population_specificity: Adults (aged 18 or older) from across Australia who had recently recovered from an episode of non-specific low back pain.
effective_dosage: Individualized, progressive walking and education facilitated by six sessions with a physiotherapist across 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of multicomponent exercises, including walking, on physical functions (muscle strength, balance, endurance) and quality of life in frail elderly individuals.
results_summary: Multicomponent exercises significantly improved muscle strength, balance, and endurance but showed no statistically significant effect on walking speed or conclusive evidence for enhancing quality of life.
population_specificity: Frail elderly individuals in communities.
study_duration: Interventions ranged from shorter than 6 weeks to 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a multidisciplinary educational intervention, including daily walking, in reducing musculoskeletal pain among elderly nursing home residents.
results_summary: The study proposed a multifaceted intervention, including daily walking for at least 30 minutes, alongside other measures like vitamin D intake and stress management, to address musculoskeletal pain. The abstract does not provide specific results but outlines the planned evaluation at multiple time points post-intervention.
population_specificity: Elderly people aged 60 years and over living in a nursing home with musculoskeletal pain.
effective_dosage: Daily walking for at least 30 minutes.
study_duration: Interventions will be evaluated before, after, 3, and 6 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the feasibility of an mHealth and VR-based integrated rehabilitation model combining nutrition, exercise, and psychology for Chinese cancer patients, including walking as part of the physical activity prescription.
results_summary: The study found no significant statistical difference in 6-minute walking speed, but improvements were noted in muscle mass and quality of life. Nutrition interventions showed the highest compliance, while exercise adherence was lower.
population_specificity: Chinese cancer patients receiving standard anti-cancer therapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified for walking; intervention included hospitalized group-based exercise classes and at-home physical activity prescription.
study_duration: 8 weeks (two hospitalization periods and two home-based rehabilitation periods).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether integrating dietary counseling into a pulmonary rehabilitation program could improve dietary intake and physical function in participants.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in protein and energy intake, muscle mass index, and physical function (e.g., chair stand test and walking distance) after the intervention, with benefits largely maintained at three-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 70.8) undergoing pulmonary rehabilitation across five municipal centers.
effective_dosage: Three sessions of individual dietary counseling during a 10-week program.
study_duration: 10 weeks (with follow-up at three months for two municipalities).

study_goal: The study aimed to investigate the safety and efficacy of cardiac shockwave therapy (SWT) in improving cardiac function and physical capacity in patients with ischemic heart failure, not Walking.
results_summary: The study found that cardiac SWT improved left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) and physical capacity (measured by a 6-minute walking test) compared to sham treatment in patients with ischemic heart failure. No direct findings related to Walking were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with LVEF ≤40% requiring surgical revascularization.
effective_dosage: Not mentioned (study focused on SWT, not Walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the local and remote effects of four weeks of minimalist shoe (MS) walking on foot health and posterior chain parameters in recreationally active young adults.
results_summary: The study found that walking in minimalist shoes for four weeks significantly improved foot posture and balance, with these improvements persisting after a four-week wash-out period. No significant changes were observed in other parameters like range of motion or muscle strength.
population_specificity: Recreationally active young adults (28 healthy participants, 15 female, 13 male; mean age 25.3 ± 5.3 years).
effective_dosage: 3,000 steps/day in the first week, increasing to 5,000 steps/day for the remaining three weeks.
study_duration: Four weeks of intervention plus a four-week wash-out period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding external cueing (visual, auditory, or somatosensory) to walking training improves walking, mobility, balance, fear of falling, and freezing in people with Parkinson's disease compared to walking training alone.
results_summary: Walking training with auditory cueing improved walking speed by 0.09 m/s more than walking training alone, but effects on stride length were uncertain. Visual cueing did not improve walking speed or stride length, and results for other outcomes (cadence, mobility, balance, fear of falling, freezing) remained inconclusive.
population_specificity: Ambulatory adults with Parkinson's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the accuracy, validity, and reliability of markerless camera-based 3D motion capture systems (MCBS) versus marker-based systems (MBS) for gait analysis.
results_summary: MCBS showed good-to-excellent accuracy, validity, and reliability for spatiotemporal parameters and kinematic variables of the hip and knee, but poor results for the ankle joint. Walking speed measurements were consistently excellent.
population_specificity: Not specified (general gait analysis context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the experiences of clinicians and clients in creating psychological formulations, focusing on barriers and facilitators to collaboration.
results_summary: The study identified three themes: toleration of the formulation process, development of the therapeutic relationship, and systemic factors, highlighting the importance of client readiness, empowerment, and supportive environments for collaborative formulation.
population_specificity: Clinicians and clients involved in psychological formulation processes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of blood flow restriction combined with aerobic exercise (including walking) on aerobic capacity, lower limb muscle strength, and mass in healthy adults.
results_summary: The study found that aerobic exercise with blood flow restriction, including walking, significantly improved aerobic capacity, lower limb muscle strength, and mass, though power bikes were more effective than walking or running. Intermittent pressure and younger age groups showed better outcomes.
population_specificity: Healthy adults (young and middle-aged, as well as elderly).
effective_dosage: 2-3 sessions per week, 10-45 minutes per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how chronic illness transforms self and identity and how healthcare professionals can support self-management in daily life.
results_summary: The study identified themes such as "Walking on an unstable ground" and "Modifying self and integrating a new way of living," highlighting the existential and identity challenges faced by individuals with chronic illnesses.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic illnesses

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate long-term functional changes in post-stroke spasticity patients treated with BoNT-A and intensive rehabilitation, focusing on walking performance.
results_summary: The study found consistent reduction in spasticity after each treatment cycle, but improvements in walking tests (6MWT and 10mWT) declined over time, while TUG improvements remained stable. Basal functional ambulation classification (FAC) predicted the likelihood of improvement in walking tests.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke survivors with spasticity in plantar flexor muscles.
study_duration: Not specified (multiple cycles, but exact duration not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of combining a brisk walking program with sugary snack restriction on overweight management, body composition, and glucose metabolism in young overweight women.
results_summary: The study found that combining brisk walking with sugary snack restriction led to greater improvements in glucose metabolism and body composition compared to exercise alone, with significant reductions in glucose, insulin, and HOMA-IR levels.
population_specificity: Overweight Korean women aged 20-39 with an average BMI of 24.6.
effective_dosage: Not specified (brisk walking frequency/duration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether dual-task training improves dual-task effects on gait speed and cognitive performance in stroke survivors compared to single-task training.
results_summary: Dual-task training provided superior improvements in dual-task effects on gait speed compared to single-task training, with benefits maintained at follow-up. No significant differences were observed in dual-task effects on cognitive scores between groups.
population_specificity: Forty-four individuals with stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical and safety outcomes of intensive versus standard systolic blood pressure control in older hypertensive adults with sarcopenia.
results_summary: Older hypertensive adults with sarcopenia randomized to intensive BP control experienced a lower risk of cardiovascular disease without increased adverse events compared with standard BP control.
population_specificity: Older hypertensive adults (aged ≥75 years) with sarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the impact of community-based PT/OT services, including walking-related interventions, on the health-related quality of life (HRQOL) of older breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in HRQOL outcomes, including physical function and participation in social roles, with PT cases showing greater improvement in global physical health compared to OT cases. Walking was among the impairments commonly treated in PT cases.
population_specificity: Older breast cancer survivors (age ≥ 65).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare clinical outcomes and safety after 5 or 6 weeks of non-weight bearing following a TOPIC procedure for medial osteochondral lesions of the talus.
results_summary: No significant differences were found in clinical, radiological, or safety outcomes between 5 and 6 weeks of non-weight bearing. Both groups showed improvement in pain scores (NRS) and functional outcomes (FAOS, AOFAS) without notable complications.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent a TOPIC procedure with medial malleolus osteotomy for medial osteochondral lesions of the talus.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (non-weight bearing duration: 5 or 6 weeks).

study_goal: To determine the effectiveness of Kinesio taping combined with routine physical therapy on improving gross motor function in sitting and standing among children with spastic diplegic Cerebral Palsy.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvement in gross motor function for both sitting and standing compared to the control group after 12 weeks. Kinesio taping applied in a criss-cross manner was found to be a beneficial additional approach alongside routine physical therapy.
population_specificity: Children with diagnosed spastic diplegic cerebral palsy (n=53).
effective_dosage: Not specified (Kinesio taping applied in a criss-cross manner alongside routine physical therapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of abobotulinumtoxinA on walking ability and fatigue in patients with MS-related spastic paraparesis.
results_summary: Patients showed an 11.34% improvement in walking ability (measured by 6MWT) and a 6.86% reduction in fatigue (measured by MSWS-12) after abobotulinumtoxinA injections, with improvements persisting over multiple cycles.
population_specificity: 84 patients with multiple sclerosis and spastic paraparesis of the lower limbs.
study_duration: 4 cycles of injections (duration per cycle not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a home exercise program, including walking, on stroke patients' upper extremity motor functions and activities of daily living.
results_summary: The study found that both the Tele-CIMT group and the control group underwent a home exercise program that included walking, but the abstract does not specify the direct effects of walking alone. Significant improvements were noted in upper extremity motor functions and daily living activities in the Tele-CIMT group.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with upper extremity motor impairments.
effective_dosage: Not specified for walking alone; the home exercise program was administered every weekday for 3 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether coronal plane angulation (varus, neutral, or valgus) affects functional and clinical outcomes, including walking ability, after fixation of distal femur fractures.
results_summary: The study found that varus angulation was associated with worse stair climbing scores and greater need for ambulatory support compared to neutral or valgus alignment, though patient-reported outcomes (SMFA, Bother Index, EQ-5D) showed no statistical differences. Walking distance ability was unaffected by alignment at any time point.
population_specificity: 156 patients with distal femur fractures, with follow-up data available for 123 patients at 12 months.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (surgical intervention: lateral locked plating or retrograde intramedullary nailing).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of activity-oriented physiotherapy (AOPT) and its combination with eye movement training (AOPT-E) on balance, walking speed, functional mobility, and eye movements in patients with Parkinson's disease (PD), and to explore the feasibility of a full-scale RCT.
results_summary: The study found improvements in dynamic balance, walking speed, functional and dual-task mobility, ability to safely balance, HRQoL, and depression, with some effects sustained at follow-up. Eye movement improvements were observed only in the AOPT-E group, and feasibility targets for recruitment, retention, and adherence were met despite COVID-19 restrictions.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease (PD)
effective_dosage: Supervised interventions were performed for 30 minutes, 4 times weekly

study_goal: The researchers examined two cases of severe hypokalemia linked to electronic cigarette use containing etomidate, focusing on its impact on walking ability due to muscle weakness.
results_summary: Both patients experienced lower limb weakness and difficulty walking due to hypokalemia, which improved after potassium supplementation. Adrenal hyperplasia and hormonal imbalances were also observed.
population_specificity: Two hospitalized patients with severe hypokalemia and adrenal hyperplasia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of cued motor imagery (CMI), cued gait training (CGT), and combined CMI-CGT on motor, cognitive, and emotional functioning, as well as health-related quality of life in people with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: None of the interventions (CMI, CGT, or CMI-CGT) demonstrated superiority in improving walking speed or distance, with negligible effects on walking speed. The study also found no significant improvements in secondary outcomes such as cognitive function, emotional well-being, or quality of life.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (MS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high-calorie-expenditure training program, including walking, could lead to greater weight loss and improvements in body composition and glycemic indices compared to standard exercise in overweight women.
results_summary: The study found significant weight loss in both high- and standard-calorie-expenditure groups, with additional improvements in muscle percentage and BMI in the high-calorie-expenditure group. Ongoing analyses suggest potential benefits for glycemic indices and inflammation factors.
population_specificity: 33 women with a BMI of 25-29.9 (overweight range).
effective_dosage: 5 sessions per week at 50%-75% maximum oxygen rate (VO2 max), expending approximately 3000-3500 kilocalories/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between cognitive impairment and physical performance, including walking speed, in middle-aged to older patients receiving maintenance haemodialysis.
results_summary: The study found that 4-m walking speed was a protective factor against cognitive impairment, while slower performance in the Timed Up and Go Test was a risk factor. Physical performance measures, including walking, were correlated with cognitive status in this population.
population_specificity: Middle-aged to older patients (55-85 years) receiving maintenance haemodialysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of combining repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (rTMS) with task-specific training on gait performance in individuals with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The combination of rTMS with treadmill training and weight-bearing exercises significantly improved walking efficiency, including walking speed, self-mobility, and step rate. High-frequency rTMS targeting the primary motor cortex showed promise in enhancing gait performance.
population_specificity: Individuals with Parkinson's disease experiencing gait disturbances.

study_goal: To investigate the effects of balance exercise and brisk walking on nonmotor and motor symptoms, balance, gait functions, walking capacity, and balance confidence in individuals with mild-to-moderate Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The combined balance and brisk walking program improved nonmotor and motor symptoms, walking capacity, balance, and gait functions post-training, with sustained benefits for motor outcomes at 6-month follow-up. Significant improvements were observed in mini-BEST score, comfortable gait speed, 6-minute walk test, and dual-task timed-Up-and-Go time.
population_specificity: Individuals with mild-to-moderate Parkinson's disease (n=99).
effective_dosage: 90-minute supervised sessions (weekly for weeks 1-6, monthly for weeks 7-26) plus unsupervised home exercises 2-3 times/week.
